text:
I'm having a problem with the stream at the moment. Trying to get multiple event types on a single call (US football, Ice Hockey, Basketball and Baseball) with the following filter:

`"marketFilter":{"marketTypes":["MATCH_ODDS"],"eventTypeIds":["6423","7522","7524","7511"]},"marketDataFilter":{"ladderLevels":10,"fields":["EX_ALL_OFFERS","EX_TRADED","EX_TRADED_VOL","EX_LTP","EX_MARKET_DEF","EX_BEST_OFFERS_DISP","SP_PROJECTED"]}`

For some reason it is only returning basketball and Americal football markets. Any ideas as to what could be causing this. I have a 1000 market limit per stream connection and I can't see a problem with that being exceeded (visually checking on the BF website rough numbers). Any suggestions? What normally happens if your required markets exceed your limit? I'd always thought your sub was refused in such cases?

For some reason it is only returning basketball and Americal football markets. Any ideas as to what could be causing this. I have a 1000 market limit per stream connection and I can't see a problem with that being exceeded (visually checking on the BF website rough numbers). Any suggestions? What normally happens if your required markets exceed your limit? I'd always thought your sub was refused in such cases?

text: Baseball out of season?

elements.text: Baseball out of season?

text: Sure, I get why no baseball - but why no ice hockey?

text: Think it's MONEY_LINE you're after for ice hockey

elements.text: Think it's MONEY_LINE you're after for ice hockey

text: Ahh thanks <@U01MPC0GUK1> I will give that a try

text: What <@U80AMMRKP> said. For Ice Hockey you're looking for "RT_MATCH_ODDS" or "MONEY_LINE"

elements.text: What
said. For Ice Hockey you're looking for "RT_MATCH_ODDS" or "MONEY_LINE"

text: Or RT_MATCH_ODDS for markets with the tie

elements.text: Or RT_MATCH_ODDS for markets with the tie

text: Many thanks chaps that has worked.

elements.text: Many thanks chaps that has worked.

text: Does anyone have a working knowledge of Timeforms abbreviations? I've seen their TFR have a `t` and `f` and can't deduce what they mean. No obvious answers in their <https://www.timeform.com/horse-racing/features/guides/abbreviations>

elements.text: Does anyone have a working knowledge of Timeforms abbreviations? I've seen their TFR have a
t
and
f
and can't deduce what they mean. No obvious answers in their

text:
if anyone is interested, I think `t` is "total" that takes into account the horses full form. `p` is based on past form and `f` is future capability.

Any improvements on those answers, let me know.

elements.text: if anyone is interested, I think
t
is "total" that takes into account the horses full form.
p
is based on past form and
f

is future capability.

Any improvements on those answers, let me know.

text: How easy/time consuming would it be for a novice in python to set up a data recording/storage system such as Liam suggested in another thread (flumine > aws s3)?

elements.text: How easy/time consuming would it be for a novice in python to set up a data recording/storage system such as Liam suggested in another thread (flumine > aws s3)?

text: easy, as all you need to do is follow liams tutorial (and get a s3-bucket)

elements.text: easy, as all you need to do is follow liams tutorial (and get a s3-bucket)

text: note that betfair wouldnt like if you only record data and never place any bets, so make sure you have something that places small amounts preferably at tight markets.

elements.text: note that betfair wouldnt like if you only record data and never place any bets, so make sure you have something that places small amounts preferably at tight markets.

text: Thanks Aaron, I didn’t realise there was a tutorial

elements.text: Thanks
Aaron,
I didn’t
realise there was a tutorial

text: <https://betcode-org.github.io/flumine/> has good info for getting started. In the flumine repo under examples, you ll find the S3Recorder, which can be used to safe streaming data in a s3-bucket. The s3 recorder can be set up just like any strategy (so you can follow the steps from the link)

elements.text: has good info for getting started. In the flumine repo under examples, you ll find the S3Recorder, which can be used to safe streaming data in a s3-bucket. The s3 recorder can be set up just like any strategy (so you can follow the steps from the link)

text: as someone who also started using flumine early on in his coding career, i want to add that while its all technically "easy", as a beginner you are likely to get stuck on the most dumb things (at least i did), so with this i d like to relativize the word "easy" as to not make you feel dumb, which may happen anyway :D

text:
Currently I have code where I cancel any unmatched bets I have and then afterwards places new bets at new prices.

So the code looks something like this:
For runner in runners:
   Camcel bet
For runners in runners:
   Place bet

I want to make sure any executable or pending bets are cancelled first before placing these new bets. What's the best way to do that? Currently the cancel order will be submitted but before the order gets cancelled it's matched while the new order also gets submitted.

elements.text:
Currently I have code where I cancel any unmatched bets I have and then afterwards places new bets at new prices.

So the code looks something like this:
For runner in runners:
   Camcel bet
For runners in runners:
   Place bet

I want to make sure any executable or pending bets are cancelled first before placing these new bets. What's the best way to do that? Currently the cancel order will be submitted but before the order gets cancelled it's matched while the new order also gets submitted.

text: you can do a check on `runner_context.live_trade_count`

elements.text: you can do a check on
runner_context.live_trade_count
